1. When the firing angle of a thyristor in a controlled rectifier circuit is increased, what happens to the average output load voltage?

explanations.c: Explanation 3: Increasing the firing angle will reduce the conduction time of the thyristors resulting in reduced output load voltage.

questions.question: 2. In a controlled rectifier circuit, what is the use of the firing angle control?

answers.a: To adjust the ripple frequency of the output.
answers.c: To change the phase shift of the input AC voltage.
answers.d: To filter the AC input signal.

explanations.b: Explanation 2: Changing the firing angle will change the conduction time of the thyristors and hence the output load voltage can easily be controlled.

questions.question: 3. What is the primary advantage of using an LC-filter over a C-filter in a controlled rectifier circuit?

answers.a: LC filter is simpler and more compact.
answers.b: LC filters provide better ripple attenuation and improve the quality of the DC output.
answers.c: LC filter is easy to design and implement.
answers.d: LC filters allow higher ripple frequency compared to C filters.

explanations.b: Explanation 2: Capacitive filter reduces the output voltage ripple. However, inductive filter reduces the output current ripple. Hence, ripple attenuation is more with LC filter.

questions.question: 4. What is the effect of increasing the load resistance in LC-filter based controlled bridge rectifier?

answers.d: The output voltage ripple increases due to decreased current through the inductor.

explanations.d: Explanation 4: Increasing the load resistance will reduce the current through it and hence the ripple percentage will be higher.

questions.question: 5. In a controlled rectifier circuit with an LC filter, if the firing angle of the thyristors is increased, what happens to the ripple frequency of the output voltage?

explanations.c: Explanation 3: Output ripple voltage frequency is independent of firing angle.
